Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: I was at my desk, reviewing invoices, when the vendor’s automated payment confirmation pinged into my inbox. As the company’s accountant, I knew I needed to send a formal reply—our policy was clear, and clients and vendors expected prompt, professional communication. I started drafting the email, but then the building’s alarms blared, and my phone vibrated with a flash-flood warning. I glanced out the window; water was already pooling along the curb, rising fast. As a citizen, I felt a surge of responsibility—should I help alert neighbors, check on the elderly couple next door, or move my car to higher ground? But the vendor’s message sat open on my screen, a reminder of my duty to keep business running smoothly. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: the company needed me to be reliable and responsive, but my community needed me to act, to be present and helpful in a crisis. I stared at the screen, torn between the roles, feeling the pressure of both demands closing in.
